He too, we may con- jecture, led the young Cicero to feel the importance ofa study of philosophy to serve as a corrective for the somewhat narrow rhetorical discipline of the time'.

Cicero's hrst systematic lessons in philosophy were given him by the Epicurean Phaedrus, then at Rome because of the unsettled state of Athens His lectures Cicero attended at avery early age, even before he had assumed thc toga virilis The pupil seems to have been converted at once to the tenets of the master'. Phaedrus remained to the end of his life a friend of Cicero, who speaks warmly in praise of his teacher's amiable disposition and rehned style. He is the only Epicurean, with, perhaps, the exception of Lucretius, whom the orator ever allows to possess any literary power⁴. Cicero soon abandoned Epicureanism, but his schoolfellow‚ T. Pomponius Atticus, received more lasting impressions from the teaching of Phaedms.
